item.title: Region Boiling, Israel Takes Up Castle Strategy
item.description: As Israel faces threats both from traditional Shiite adversaries like Iran and from extremist Sunni cells in Syria, Iraq and beyond, officials have embraced a castle mentality.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: An Israeli security coordinator near Kiryat Shmona stood by the remains of a rocket fired from Lebanon last month.

item.title: Turkey Extends Purge of Officials
item.description: Turkey has fired dozens of banking and telecoms regulators and state television executives in moves that appear to broaden the Prime Ministerâ€™s response to a corruption investigation.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Iraq Bombings and Fighting Kill Dozens
item.description: A series of car bombings and fighting between militants and government troops over control of Anbar Province killed at least 30 people Saturday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Q. and A.: In Syria, Former Official Says, â€˜Nobody Is Winningâ€™
item.description: Excerpts from an interview with Jihad Makdissi, a former Foreign Ministry spokesman in Syria who fled in 2012 as the government cracked down on protesters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Ex-Official Claims to Speak for Sidelined Syrians
item.description: Jihad Makdissi, the former Foreign Ministry spokesman, has resurfaced, a rare high-profile dissenter seeking to position himself as a voice for many Syrians who remain on the sidelines.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HALA DROUBI
item.media:description: Jihad Makdissi, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, in July 2012. He left his post later that year.

item.title: Iran Diplomat Dies in Yemen After Shooting
item.description: Gunmen killed Ali Asghar Asadi, an economic attachÃ©, in a drive-by shooting in the Yemeni capital, Sana, in the latest attack on Iranâ€™s diplomatic corps in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Overwhelming Vote for Egyptâ€™s Constitution Raises Concern
item.description: The voters approved a revised constitution validating last summerâ€™s military takeover and paving the way for Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, the countryâ€™s top military leader, to seek the presidency.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Intensive Security for Winter Olympics
item.description: As the Winter Games approach, tens of thousands of personnel and surveillance cameras have been deployed to Sochi. Critics say the measures threaten to temper the Olympic spirit.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Cossack officer is among hundreds who are joining regular security forces at Olympic venues like Rosa Khutor, a skiing center.

item.title: 9 in Haiti Accused in Journalist Case
item.description: A judge in Port-au-Prince accused nine people, including friends of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, of having had a hand in the killing of the radio journalist Jean Dominique.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Greek Prosecutors Focus on Corruption at the Top
item.description: Corruption cases are being pursued against a widening pool of current and former high-ranking government officials and members of the business gentry once deemed untouchable.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:credit: Dimitris Kotsakis/In Time News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Michalis Liapis, a former minister, is accused of using European subsidies to renovate a home.

item.title: After Love Unravels in Media, Indian Politicianâ€™s Wife Is Found Dead
item.description: The death of Sunanda Pushkar stunned many in Delhiâ€™s journalistic and political circles, many of whom had followed the twists in her life since she met Shashi Tharoor.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Sunanda Pushkar, left, and Shashi Tharoor at their wedding reception in 2010.

item.title: Deadly Attack at Kabul Restaurant Hints at Changing Climate for Foreigners
item.description: Kabul during the Afghan war was never violent as Baghdad during the Iraq war. But as coalition forces leave, international workers here feel more vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Saturday, an Afghan man cleaned his car, which was destroyed during an attack at a restaurant in central Kabul on Friday.

item.title: Syrian Opposition Votes to Attend Peace Talks
item.description: The vote was boycotted by a third of the members of the main rebel coalition, a reflection of the intense divisions among those seeking to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Russian Forces Kill 7 Suspected of an Attack
item.description: The seven people killed were suspected of carrying out a grenade and bomb attack outside a restaurant in the region of Dagestan.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: South Sudan Recaptures Town From Rebels
item.description: The government said it had won a significant military victory by seizing the city of Bor in Jonglei State.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: A Stampede of Mourners in India Kills at Least 18
item.description: Hundreds were packed into narrow lanes trying to get a glimpse of the body of the spiritual leader Syedna Mohammad Burhanuddin when the stampede occurred.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Hundreds of people gathered in Mumbai to pay their respects to Syedna Mohammed Burhanuddin, who was the leader of the Dawoodi Bohra community.

item.title: News Analysis: Yahooâ€™s Asian Lifeline
item.description: Despite the companyâ€™s recent shake-up, Wall Street still likes its valuable holdings in China and Japan.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF SOMMER
item.media:description: Marissa Mayer, chief of Yahoo, at the International CES in Las Vegas.

item.title: In Keeping Grip on Data Pipeline, Obama Does Little to Reassure Industry
item.description: While President Obama bolstered some protections for citizens, he did nothing, at least yet, to address the data security concerns of U.S. technology companies.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER
item.media:description: President Obama on Friday announced changes in a contentious surveillance program that has swept up many millions of records of Americansâ€™ cellphone calls, though not their content.

item.title: India Ink: What They Said: Rahul Gandhiâ€™s Speech at Congress Executive Meeting
item.description: In an unusually passionate address on Friday, Rahul Gandhi praised the governing party as the defenders of the peopleâ€™s will and criticized the main opposition as being undemocratic.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 18 Die in Stampede in Mumbai
item.description: At least 18 people died early Saturday in a stampede as tens of thousands of members of a Muslim sect gathered to mourn the death of their spiritual leader in Mumbai.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Suchitra Sen, Actress Famed in Bengali Cinema, Dies at 82
item.description: After more than 50 films, Ms. Sen retired and became a recluse.
item.dc:creator: By HARESH PANDYA

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Signs of Unrest Raise Alarms
item.description: The United States urged Myanmar to investigate reports that security forces and Buddhist mobs attacked members of the Rohingya Muslim minority, killing as many as 60 people.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Lawmaker Defends Shrine Visit
item.description: A top Japanese lawmaker on Friday denounced American criticism of Prime Minister Shinzo Abeâ€™s visit last month to a Tokyo war shrine.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying
item.description: In a speech that seemed more calculated to reassure audiences at home and abroad than to force radical change, President Obama announced significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: President Obama set out his policies on surveillance by the government in a speech at the Justice Department on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Contentious Medical Bill Signed
item.description: President Abdullah Gul signed a measure into law on Friday that makes it a crime to administer emergency first aid without government authorization.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
